description: From Middle English chiden (“to chide, rebuke, disapprove, criticize; complain, grumble, dispute; argue, debate, dispute, quarrel”), from Old English ċīdan (“to chide, reprove, rebuke; blame, contend, strive, quarrel, complain”). Cognate with German kiden (“to sound”); Old High German kīdal (“wedge”).

verbs.description: chide (third-person singular simple present chides, present participle chiding, simple past chid or chided or chode, past participle chid or chided or chidden)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To admonish in blame; to reproach angrily.
(intransitive, obsolete) To utter words of disapprobation and displeasure; to find fault; to contend angrily.
(transitive, intransitive) To make a clamorous noise; to chafe.
